Title: A BLESSING ON YOUR HOUSE
Description: METAL ELEPHANT (GANESH) on lucite block on nails with patina copper arch with adorable couple just about to kiss
Biography:
When Nancy Slonim Aronie was eight, she told her big sister, "I’m going to be an artist when I grow up”. Four years older and Nancy’s idol, her sister said, “You can't. I’m going to be an artist. You can be a writer.” Aronie went on to write three books, was a commentator for National Public Radio’s “All Things Considered” and currently has a bi-weekly column in the Martha’s Vineyard Times. But her memory of the heartbreak she felt being in art class in elementary school, when the teacher would say ,“Now children, put away your materials,” must have stayed and marinated in her artist soul.

In her thirties she began finger painting on wood, making pieces out of found objects, buying goodies in antique shops and enclosing them in plexiglass boxes. For the last fifty years she has been telling stories, using multimedia art. Aronie, her husband Joel, who does much of the construction on her work and her two sons spent summers on the Vineyard beginning in the early seventies. The family moved here year round twenty five years ago.

Old bird feeder, Tin roof, Three bathing beauties

Lucite panel
on lucite 8” base

Biography:
When Nancy Slonim Aronie was eight, she told her big sister, "I’m going to be an artist when I grow up”. Four years older and Nancy’s idol, her sister said, “You can't. I’m going to be an artist. You can be a writer.” Aronie went on to write three books, was a commentator for National Public Radio’s “All Things Considered” and currently has a bi-weekly column in the Martha’s Vineyard Times. But her memory of the heartbreak she felt being in art class in elementary school, when the teacher would say ,“Now children, put away your materials,” must have stayed and marinated in her artist soul.

In her thirties she began finger painting on wood, making pieces out of found objects, buying goodies in antique shops and enclosing them in plexiglass boxes. For the last fifty years she has been telling stories, using multimedia art. Aronie, her husband Joel, who does much of the construction on her work and her two sons spent summers on the Vineyard beginning in the early seventies. The family moved here year round twenty five years ago.

Title: Rock Climbing
